media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CALIF. - APR. 25, 2020. Beachgowers set up on Huntington Beach, where afternoon fog and cool temperatures limited the number of visitors to Orange County beaches on Saturday, April 25, 2020. More people were expected to go to the coast to escape record high heat in some inland areas. Beaches in neighboring Los Angeles County remain closed because of the coronavirus pandemic. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

LAUSD is providing meals to students in the wake of school closures as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. North Hills, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Gov. Gavin Newsom says staying home now will help reopen California sooner
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom urged Californians to stay home to avoid undoing the progress the state has made in fighting the spread of the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom urged Californians to stay home to avoid undoing the progress the state has made in fighting the spread of the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Tuesday, April 14, 2020, file photo, California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses an outline for what it will take to lift coronavirus restrictions during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. On a near daily basis since outlining his criteria for someday easing stay-at-home orders, Newsom, who recently allowed scheduled surgeries to resume, has warned Californians that, while he understands their desires to get back to work and a sense of normalcy, lifting the orders too soon could be a public health mistake. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool, File)

item.title: Who can get a coronavirus test and how long does it take to get results?
item.dc:creator: Lila Seidman
item.description: It's slowly getting easier to obtain a coronavirus test in California — following an initial rollout marked by restrictions and shortages.
item.content:encoded: It's slowly getting easier to obtain a coronavirus test in California — following an initial rollout marked by restrictions and shortages.

media:content.media:description: CARSON, CA - APRIL 28, 2020 - - California Assemblyman Mike A. Gipson, of the Sixty-Fourth District, does self-testing at a new drive-up testing site for COVID-19 outside the East Wing of the Congresswoman Juanita Millender-McDonald Community Center in Carson on April 28, 2020. Free COVID-19 testing is available to all city residents thanks to a partnership between the city and US Health Fairs. Carson is the first Southern California city to offer free testing to all its residents. Mayor Albert Robles and members of the Carson City Council also did self-testing at the opening of the new test site. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Terminal Island prison inmates have worst coronavirus outbreak in federal system
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: As of Tuesday, 443 of the prison's 1,055 inmates have the coronavirus, along with 10 staff members. Two inmates have died from COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: As of Tuesday, 443 of the prison's 1,055 inmates have the coronavirus, along with 10 staff members. Two inmates have died from COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO CA. APRIL 29, 2020 -- Exterior view of the Federal Correctional Institution Terminal Island in San Pedro. Nearly half of the inmates at the federal prison at Terminal Island in San Pedro have tested positive for the coronavirus in what had has become the nation's worst outbreak in a federal penitentiary. As of Tuesday, 443 of the prison's 1,055 inmates have the virus, along with 10 staff members. Two inmates have already died of complications related to COVID-19, according to the Bureau of Prisons. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. businesswoman fighting back after police accuse her of breaking stay-at-home rules
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: Coronavirus: L.A. businesswoman fights back after being charged with violating stay-at-home rule
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus: L.A. businesswoman fights back after being charged with violating stay-at-home rule

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 16, 2020: Natali Mishali grabs a quick phone call while at DTLA Smoke Shop on April 16, 2020, in Los Angeles, California. In early April, Mishali's shop was one of the first four in the city of Los Angeles criminally charged for refusing to shut down during the quarantine as city officials deemed the smoke shop a non-essential business. Mishali claimed for weeks that her store should have been allowed to operate as an essential business since it sold dry goods, paper products and cleaning supplies. The city eventually confirmed to her that she was in violation of state law. ({Dania Maxwell} / {Los Angeles Times})

item.title: With laboratories shut, coronavirus forces scientists to 'stop cold'
item.dc:creator: Joel Rubin, Amina Khan
item.description: The coronavirus outbreak has put science on hold. Now there are discoveries that may never be made and patients who will miss the chance at a breakthrough cure.
item.content:encoded: The coronavirus outbreak has put science on hold. Now there are discoveries that may never be made and patients who will miss the chance at a breakthrough cure.

media:content.media:description: BEVERLY HILLS, CA - APRIL 21, 2020 - - Dr. Nader Pouratian, an associate professor of Neurosurgery Brain Research at UCLA, stands in front of his home in Beverly Hills on Tuesday, April 21, 2020. Dr. Pouratian developed a device that gives a type of artificial sight to blind people and had implanted the device in the brains of four people. The four participants were part of a small clinical trial at UCLA that has been suspended. The pandemic has had an impact on scientific research as universities and other institutions have closed laboratories and suspended many clinical trials. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: A family of strawberry growers had big dreams. Then came the pandemic
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hernandez
item.description: The Carranza family worked on the McGrath Family Farm for more than 20 years. Just as they sought to go into the strawberry business on their own, the coronavirus hit.
item.content:encoded: The Carranza family worked on the McGrath Family Farm for more than 20 years. Just as they sought to go into the strawberry business on their own, the coronavirus hit.

media:content.media:description: OXNARD, CA-APRIL 1, 2020: left to right-Cruz Carranza, 46, his father Javier, 61, and brother Flavio, 21, are photographed on a strawberry field that they grow the berries on at McGrath Family Farm in Oxnard. The Carranza family has been living and working at McGrath Family Farm, one of the oldest organic family farms in California, for 20 years, but it was only this year that they decided to plant strawberries on their own, within the farm. As peak season approaches for strawberries, the immigrant family from the state of Michoachan, Mexico are seeing dropping sales and fewer places to sell their berries because of the coronavirus outbreak. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - APRIL 06: Dr. Lisa Dabby, 41, left, an emergency room physician with UCLA Medical Center in Santa Monica talks with nursing staff at the entrance to the temporary initial screening area assembled in the covered entrance to the hospital emergency room where they are on the front line of the coronavirus COVID-19 outbreak. During a typical 10-hour shift, she treats appendicitis, overdoses, skateboard accidents, arrhythmia, the usual off-the-street accidents, illnesses and conditions that flare up without notice. With more than 10 years at the hospital, she knows what to expect and how to treat it, but the coronavirus has changed that. She treats about 20 patients a day who arrive with coughs, fevers, shortness of breath and the fear and uncertainty that this pandemic has brought. UCLA Medical Center, Santa Monica on Monday, April 6, 2020 in Santa Monica, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Glowing blue waves lighting up SoCal coastline roll into the South Bay
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Mark Potts, Jay L. Clendenin
item.description: Video and photos show an algae bloom in the South Bay producing a neon-blue light along the shoreline at night in Hermosa Beach.
item.content:encoded: Video and photos show an algae bloom in the South Bay producing a neon-blue light along the shoreline at night in Hermosa Beach.

media:content.media:description: HERMOSA BEACH, CA - APRIL 25: Bioluminescent waves glow off the coast of Hermosa Beach, CA, Saturday, April 25, 2020. The phenomenon is associated with a red tide, or an algae bloom, filled with dinoflagellates which react with bioluminescence when jostled by the moving water. During the daytime, due to the pigmentation of the dinoflagellates, the water can turn a deep red, brown, or orange color, giving red tides their name.(Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Jay L. Clendenin/Jay L. Clendenin/Los Angeles Times

item.description: A former contestant on "The Voice" leads a weekly performance in her Upland cul-de-sac where neighbors connect to get through the pandemic together.
item.content:encoded: A former contestant on "The Voice" leads a weekly performance in her Upland cul-de-sac where neighbors connect to get through the pandemic together.

media:content.media:description: UPLAND, CA - APRIL 16: Alexa Capelli, a 20-year-old singer, who lives in the culdesac, sings at her neighborhood weekly gathering. Neighbors living in a culdesac of Upland got together and hold Neighborhood Safe Social Distancing gathering on weekly basis to keep the mood upbeat in the midst coronavirus pandemic. Alexa Capelli, a 20-year-old singer, who lives in the culdesac at 1400 block of Highpoint Street, entertains the neighbors with beautiful songs. Neighbors, who come from different professional background, like occupational therapist, law enforcement, school teacher, medical office administrator, x-ray technician and owner of thrift store, bring out their lawn chair and tables, sipping on their favorite drinks enjoy the weekly musical evening. Upland, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

Gavin Newsom discusses an outline for what it will take to lift coronavirus restrictions during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. On a near daily basis since outlining his criteria for someday easing stay-at-home orders, Newsom, who recently allowed scheduled surgeries to resume, has warned Californians that, while he understands their desires to get back to work and a sense of normalcy, lifting the orders too soon could be a public health mistake. media:content.media:description: MADERA, CALIFORNIA-APRIL 8, 2020-Juan Infante, a certified medical assistant, takes the temperature of a patient (who approved her photograph being taken) before she gets tested for Covid-19. Camarena Health Center is working together with the Madera County Rapid Contact Tracing Team to help identify and isolate people who have tested positive or come into contact with a coronavirus carrier. The Madera County Rapid Contact Tracing Team is a model program to identify anyone who has come into contact with a person who tests positive for Covid 19 coronavirus. They identify those who need to go into home quarantine and possibly house them at a hotel if needed. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Californians battling unemployment amid coronavirus are stymied by state agency's tech issues
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy, Kim Christensen
item.description: For Californians desperate to get help from the state unemployment office, the last month has been a perfect storm of technological failures.
item.content:encoded: For Californians desperate to get help from the state unemployment office, the last month has been a perfect storm of technological failures.

media:content.media:description: Unionized hospitality workers wait in line in a basement garage to apply for unemployment benefits at the Hospitality Training Academy Friday, March 13, 2020, in Los Angeles. Fearing a widespread health crisis, Californians moved broadly Friday to get in front of the spread of the coronavirus, shuttering schools that educate hundreds of thousands of students, urging the faithful to watch religious services online and postponing or scratching just about any event that could attract a big crowd. (AP Photo/Marcio Jose Sanchez)

item.content:encoded: The coronavirus spread with deadly speed through Riverside jail. Could it have been stopped?

(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Battling lockdown fatigue, California messages both hope and fear. Will it work?
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna
item.description: In years past, the county and city have struggled to effectively communicate with the public during emergencies. This time, they're focusing on a consistent message.
item.content:encoded: In years past, the county and city have struggled to effectively communicate with the public during emergencies. This time, they're focusing on a consistent message.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-APRIL 22, 2020: A group of protesters including Alma Villanueva, left, and Gigi Wilcox, right, stage a vehicle caravan protest to call on state and local officials to re-open the economy in downtown Los Angeles on Wednesday, April 22, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Skelton: In the coronavirus crisis, California isn't under one-party rule, it's under one-man rule
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: Power abhors a vacuum. With the legislative and judicial branches basically shut down because of the coronavirus, the executive has seized almost complete control over state government.
item.content:encoded: Power abhors a vacuum. With the legislative and judicial branches basically shut down because of the coronavirus, the executive has seized almost complete control over state government.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Tuesday, April 14, 2020, file photo, California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses an outline for what it will take to lift coronavirus restrictions during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. On a near daily basis since outlining his criteria for someday easing stay-at-home orders, Newsom, who recently allowed scheduled surgeries to resume, has warned Californians that, while he understands their desires to get back to work and a sense of normalcy, lifting the orders too soon could be a public health mistake. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool, File)

item.title: WWII veteran gets special birthday honor after party is canceled because of pandemic
item.dc:creator: City News Service
item.description: Lt. Col. Sam Sachs celebrated his 105th birthday Sunday with a parade of well-wishers in cars, military vehicles and even an appearance from a Los Angeles County sheriff's helicopter.
item.content:encoded: Lt. Col. Sam Sachs celebrated his 105th birthday Sunday with a parade of well-wishers in cars, military vehicles and even an appearance from a Los Angeles County sheriff's helicopter.

media:content.media:description: Lt. Col. Sam Sachs, a World War II veteran, celebrates his 105th birthday with well wishers at the Mom & Dad's House, an assisted living facility, in Lakewood. Lt. Col. Sachs appealed to the public for birthday cards after the coronavirus pandemic forced the cancellation of a big celebration and wound up receiving thousands, including a letter and photo from President Donald Trump. A surprise parade of cars drove by the senior living home where Sachs resides.

item.title: L.A. County reports 18 new coronavirus deaths, says poor people are three times more likely to die
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 18 additional COVID-19 deaths and 440 new cases of the coronavirus and said that people in lower-income communities are three times more likely to die of COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 18 additional COVID-19 deaths and 440 new cases of the coronavirus and said that people in lower-income communities are three times more likely to die of COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Orange County coronavirus cases near 2,000
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Hillary Davis
item.description: Orange County health officials announce 124 new cases and two more deaths, for a total of 1,969 confirmed cases and 38 deaths. The county will launch a testing network Tuesday.
item.content:encoded: Orange County health officials announce 124 new cases and two more deaths, for a total of 1,969 confirmed cases and 38 deaths. The county will launch a testing network Tuesday.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 22, 2020: Denise Martinez, of Costa Mesa, kneels down in prayer in front of the closed Huntington Beach pier as she spreads her message of love, not the anarchy that she says some of the stay-at-home protesters want. "I'm out here praying for the city," Martinez said. "And to show an example of Christ, who is love. Our freedom doesn't come from a spirit of anarchy. Right now our main focus is loving each other at any cost. The lord says today that he hears the cries of his people and to trust him. Because love overcomes everything." Beach-goers enjoyed warm summer-like weather amid state and city social distancing regulations to stave off Coronavirus mandated by Gov. Newsom in Huntington Beach, CA, on April 22, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Advocates with mask donation turned away from San Diego immigration detention center
item.dc:creator: KATE MORRISSEY
item.description: California Assemblywoman Lorena Gonzalez brought about 1,000 masks to donate to detainees at Otay Mesa Detention Center
item.content:encoded: California Assemblywoman Lorena Gonzalez brought about 1,000 masks to donate to detainees at Otay Mesa Detention Center

media:content.media:description: From the right, Lorena Gonzalez Fletcher and Claudia Watson attempted to deliver boxes containing approximately 1000 face masks. The masks are for use by ICE detainees and US Marshall inmates at the Core Civic detention center in Otay Mesa in San Diego. Attempts to deliver the mask were stopped by guards at the facility.
media:content.media:credit: Nelvin C. Cepeda/The San Diego Union-Tribune
